reviews.text:
I believe that the most enjoyable thing in the world is travelling and visiting places while taking pictures. Then sharing those memories and pictures with people is the most attractive part of travelling, for me. It is very nice knowing that sharing those pictures contributes to people’s ambition to travel. 
I think that people should learn while travelling, they make research, reads and benefit other’s experiences. I can say that sharing my experiences is very enjoyable to me. I’m curiously following the uploaded photos on Google. I want to share the photos I’ve taken via Google and I would do it with a great pleasure. 
I think that the more you visit the more you want to explore places. Visiting and taking photos of such beautiful places gives birth to the desire to share them. I wish there could be trip all around the world but I also know that every part of Turkey is beautiful, full of surprises and waiting to be discovered. I believe in making plans and taking efforts to explore more. Thanks to such sacrifices you did while travelling more places should be uncovered, shared and got what it deserved. 
Time flies and of course travelling need time and budget. Sometimes you want to be alone but sometimes you seek for a hand of a friend. But Google offers you excellent opportunities and companies which should not be ignored.

It is my favorite place in Ankara. It is very nice monumental place. You can see either Islamic forms or ancient frigian religious forms together.  In addition they has good harmony as they stand side by side forcefully.
Newly renovated square. However the place impressed. Good view on Ankara castle.
A great history you can see there
Excellent Spiritual Experience... There is a way from heart to heart...
One of the oldest Masjed in Ankara. Built in 1197. It has full of secrets. (A secret passage gate from Ankara Castle to Augustus Temple. It was sealed when they built a mosque on it in 10th century.)
After climbing up the walls you will be rewarded with an incredible 360 view of Ankara.

Ankara’da, Altındağ İlçesi’nde, Hisar semtinde, İçkale Mahallesi’nde, Ali Taşı Sokak’ta bulunmaktadır. 
Kıble duvarı İçkale suru ile bitişiktir. Güneydoğusunda hemen yanında “Zindan Kapı” ve “Parmak Kapı” olarak adlandırılan İçkale kapısı vardır. 
Ankara'nın halen ibadete açık olan en eski camiidir.

Alaeddin Camii Ankara'da, Altındağ İlçesi'nde, Hisar semtinde, İçkale Mahallesi'nde, Ali Taşı Sokak'ta bulunmaktadır. Kıble duvarı İçkale suru ile bitişiktir. Güneydoğusunda hemen yanında “Zindan Kapı” ve “Parmak Kapı” olarak adlandırılan İçkale kapısı vardır. Ankara'nın halen ibadete açık olan en eski camisidir.
İnşa tarihi kesin olarak bilinmemektedir. 
Kapısı üzerinde bulunan bir kitabeye göre; Anadolu Selçuklu Sultanı II. Kılıçaslan (1155/1192)’ın oğlu, Ankara emiri Muhiddin Mesud Şah (ö.1204) tarafından, Ankara Kalesi içinde, yaptırılmış ve H.574 (1178) yazında ibadete açılmıştır. 
Ankara’daki en eski Selçuklu yapısı olarak kabul edilmektedır. 
Minberi H.594 (1197) tarihlidir. 
Anadolu Selçuklu Sultanı Alaeddin I. Keykubad (1220-1237) tarafından onarımı yaptırıldığından “Alaeddin Camii” olarak anılmaktadır. 
Ancak, bugün gördüğümüz binanın orjinali ile hiçbir ilgi ve benzerliği yoktur. 
Temel taşları dahil bütün duvarları, tavanı, pervazları ile pencereleri, saçakları ile çatısı; 1361, 1433, 1895, 1984 de yapılan detaylı onarımlarda tamamen değiştirilerek yenilenmişlerdir.
Bulunduğu bölgede tek . Kliması çalışıyorken enfes oluyor içinde namaz kılmak.
A five centuries old mosque, rebuilt in 1940. Elegant

Mimar Sinan’nın Ankara’daki İlk Tek ve Son Eseri

Sadece Türkiye’nin değil Dünya’nın da en büyük mimarları arasında gösterilen Mimar Sinan’ın dehasını gösterdiği Ankara’daki tek eserinin “Ulucanlar Caddesi’ndeki Cenabı Ahmet Paşa Camisi” olduğunu biliyor muydunuz?

Sinan, 99 yıl 3 ay 3 günlük hayatında toplam 84 cami, 53 mescid, 57 medrese, 7 darül kurra (cami veya mescit yanında bulunan tek kubbeli kuran okuma yeri), 22 türbe, 17 imaret (yoksullara ve medrese öğrencilerine yemek verilen yer), 3 darüşşifa (sağlık yurdu), 5 suyolu kemeri, 8 köprü, 20 kervansaray (yol üstü dinlenme tesisi), 35 köşk ve saray, 8 ambar ve mahzen, 48 hamam olmak üzere 364 adet eser üretti.

Eser, giriş kapısı üzerindeki yazıta göre Kanuni Sultan Süleyman döneminde, 1566 yılında Anadolu Beylerbeyliği yapan Cenabı Ahmet Paşa tarafından Mimar Sinan’a yaptırılmıştır. 13.9x13.9 metre ölçülerinde kare planlı ve Ankara’nın kesme taşından yapılan cami 1883 ve 1887 yıllarında onarımdan geçirilmiştir. Şerefesi yine kesme taştan tek şerefeli ve 16 köşelidir. Cami 32 pencere ile aydınlatılırken, büyük kubbesi 16 pencereli bir kasnak üzerine oturtulmuştur. Caminin sol yanındaki küçük hazirede Cenabı Ahmet Paşa’nın ve XVIII.yüzyıla ait Azimi Türbesi bulunmaktadır. Sekizgen türbe 1566 yılında Mimar Sinan tarafından yapılmıştır.

Mevlevihane'nin tarihini ayrıntılı olarak bilemiyoruz. 17. yüzyılda Evliya Çelebi (1640) Mevlevihane'den söz ediyor. 1911 yılında Şeyh Mustafa Nureddin Dede, Konya'ya yazdığı mektupta çile çıkarmış dedegan olmadığından hizmetlerin fahri olarak yapıldığını bildiriyor. Son şeyh Mustafa Nuri Dede 25 dervişi ile Mevlevi alayına katılmış, cepheye gitmiştir. 1929 yılına geldiğinde avludaki tekke yapıları, askeri barakalar H. Jansen planı gereğince yıkılmış iki türbe ile hamuşan mezarlıktan küçük bir parça bırakılmıştır.

Bu cami Mimar Sinan'ın iç Anadolu'daki kendisinin bizzat gelip kontrol ettiği ve başında durduğu çıraklık eseridir. Klasik İstanbul camileri gibi kemerli ve akustik mükemmeldir. Cami'nin bahçesinde iki adet türbe ve Mevlevi bir ailenin yattığı mezarlıkta bulunmaktadır. Gezilmesini ve görülmesini kesinlikle tavsiye ederim

Mimar Sinan’ın Ankara’daki tek eseri olan cami kimse tarafından bilinmemekte etrafındaki Hacı Bayram Cami Hamamönü Ankara Kalesi Ulucanlar cezaevi gibi kıymetli yerlerin gölgesinde kalmıştır fakat o bölgede gezerken uğramak icap eden bir yerdir
Tarihi eski taş bina küçük ama bakımlı kışın ısıtma sorunu var
Because nobody takes the effort to let visiters know that the museum is closed!!!! So very bad....and unfortunately also so very Turkish
Good but not best one.

Very old building with beautiful paintings inside stretching from the Ottoman Empire to modern Turkey. The paintings are well preserved and well displayed. The galleries are spacious and calm. The sculptures are also breathtaking but few. Staff are also very nice. Highly recommend while in the Ulus area.
It deserves to be visited.
It is a bit of a compact museum with lots of stunning pieces of art. My favorites have been the sculptures of Hakkı Karayiğitoğlu.
Ankara tren garının arkasından taşındı ulaşımı kolaydı oradayken hızlı tren garı yapmak için taşıdılar.en son buradaki trenleri Anadolu bulvarından geçerken TMO arkasındaki Arsada gördüm
Не плохой музей поездов!

We and our kids enjoyed a wonderful afternoon here. Alot of activities to explore, both indoors and out, and a beautiful natural environment, complete with running steam, holds and animals roaming about.
Too much beutifully place , park is new put very nice place
Very efficient open-air museum in the heart of the city. Traditional wood & log village houses, workshops, poultry, animals. A must see.
Very peaceful and calm open air museum with wooden houses and traditional workshops. A must see!
A nice outdoor museum/park in Ankara. The service in shops and stands I visited was very friendly even though most of the staff didn't speak English. I was visiting the park with a local friend.
Decent

Fantastic museum and well worth the effort in going. You have to buy tickets online in advance for a specific time and date (and depending when you visit, usually several weeks in advance before all the time slots fill up). The audio tour is excellent, well narrated and enough information that you feel it adds something without it moving you along too fast either. The rooms are bare in the house, a decision taken by Otto Frank when he returned to Amsterdam after WW2 but it also helps the sheer volume of people move around. The allocated slots limit numbers but it will still be busy. At the end of the tour is a very moving video about Anne and how she is viewed today.
A historic site which was under maintenance when we went there but there is nothing special. Specially if you have visited other historic sites before, you won't find it interesting.
If you are interested in ancient Rome this is worth a lookaround. Gives someone the feeling how huge the building must have been. Also nice to wander around a bit.
Very big area with perfect ruins.

Alleen jammer dat ze het groen niet goed bijhouden.
Als dat weg is, heb je een geweldig uitzicht.
Prachtig gebouw midden in de stad complete stilte!
Perhaps It is most beautiful historical place in Ankara with hacı bayram Mosque
It is good and well managed place.

The Temple of Augustus and Roam in Ankara is probably the most intact copy of the Res Gestae in the world. It was built in  between 25 and 20 B.C. following the conquest of central Anatolia by the Roman, as the new capital of Galatia. After the death of Augustus in 14 A.D., his deeds were inscribed in Latin along the interior walls of the inner portico and in Greek on the columns of an exterior wall on the temple’s inner chamber. It is located in the Ulus district of Ankara, Turkey, just next to the Hacı Bayram Mosque. You can only visit the outside of the temple as it is forbidden to enter into inside of this ancient place.
Overall a beautiful place specially its entrance but nothing special.
Beautiful

Very big area with perfect ruins.
Free entry.. Perhaps one of the very few interesting places in Ankara. You'll find all about Ataturk.. his pictures, life size wax statue and his grave. Must visit place!

The place as a poetic painting of every part in which a description of the championship and courage.The fragrant anniversary and long history of the heroes of this great country.You can feel the spirit of heroes and brave fighters and you wander around this great edifice.
I love it.

A magnificent complex perfectly encapsulating the importance of Atatürk as founder and shaper of the modern Republic of Turkey. This is definitely one of the foremost sights for any visitor to Ankara. Just remember that this is almost a sacred place for many Turks and so act especially respectful here.
After Traveling to ankara I felt in love with the city! Amazing! Best city in middle east! Specially Young people are great in Turkey. Love it

Minimalistic monument, nice to see. When we visited it was snowing heavily so it wasn’t so easy to approach cause the stairs were frozen and it was slippery. Besides the weather conditions, there aren’t many signs so we didn’t even realise there was also a museum and not just the monument so we missed that part which I later heard was the best part :/ And the securities on the entrance were really nice and friendly.

First night out on my own in Ankara and came across this place. Amazing. Staff were friendly and welcoming- attentive but not intrusive. The food was incredible! As well as the dips, fruit, nuts and tea which were provided at various stages of the meal free of charge, I had a kind of baked hummus with breadcrumbs on the top, and a chicken, tomato, mozzarella, aubergine thing. More food than I could possibly have eaten (although it was delicious so I gave it a damn good go) - the bread alone (which they arranged the poppy seeds on top of to spell ENG when they found out I was from England) was about 50cm long! All for 55lira (£8 / 10USD). Clearly a favourite with Turkish families- I can see why- and I’ll be going back next time I’m in Ankara.

So I am hesitant on what review to leave here, but based on the end of my meal I think 2 stars is valid. I am American and believe it impacted our service, my fiancee is Turkish and at the start our service from the waiter was very good. The food is pretty decent with a decent atmosphere.

The problem came at the end of our meal. When we were getting check he asked if we wanted to leave a tip. We were taken aback as my fiancee says, they don't ask for tips in Turkey. When I offered a tip it was clearly not to his liking and he refused it. He was very rude and was clearly expecting a large tip from an American. To be clear, in Turkey, tips are not normal. I do leave small tips to my favorite restaurant, but this place was very rude. This may not be a normal thing a the restaurant, but it put a large damper on a lovely evening.
Delicious food - acceptable service - interesting thing with bread: they pour sesame on it in shape of a word. For us, it was our country. Overall a good cozy place for families.
Hospitality, delicious meals, smiling faces and more thanks for everything
Great taste with a great staff and atmosphere.
Same quality service and good taste everytime I visit. Perfection in another language. 😁
Great food and complimentary starters. A bit pricey for Ankara. Good sushi, Chinese and Japanese cuisine.
This restaurant serves sushi, noodle varieties, Chinese food and a considerable selection of wine. Bento boxes are available. It's not cheap. Well-decorated and clean.

The atmosphere is breathtaking and quite authentic with the fixtures and the statues. The food is delicious and there are plenty of options. The cocktails are great and not too expensive. The service staff is helpful and friendly. Reservations are recommended especially for evening hours.
Pricy but tasty. Portions are smaller than I expected.
